title: Tangential flow filtration of ceria slurry: Application of a single-pass method to improve buff cleaning
abstract: Ceria slurries are used in the oxide chemical mechanical polishing (CMP) process due to their high polishing performance and selectivity characteristics. However, it takes great effort to remove small ceria particles that remain on the wafer surface during the post-CMP cleaning process. Therefore, we applied tangential flow filtration (TFF) systems, which can be used to separate small ceria particles before CMP process. In a previous study, we improved the post-CMP cleaning efficiency of the ceria slurry with a circulation-type TFF system. Herein, the correlations between the separation rate of ceria particles and parameters affecting the TFF system, such as membrane pore size, flow rate, and transmembrane pressure (TMP), were evaluated to improve buff cleaning efficiency. Finally, we also fabricated a single-pass TFF system to reduce the process time and loss of active ceria particles. With the single-pass TFF system, the basic properties and polishing performance of the ceria slurry did not change. In addition, the buff cleaning efficiency improved by up to 18.1%.

sections.Introduction:
1
                  Introduction
                  Technology development has resulted in the miniaturization and high integration of semiconductors, with trends in device manufacturing shifting from 2D-NAND to 3D-NAND flash memory. Chemical mechanical polishing (CMP) is an important process in device manufacturing for DRAM and 2D/3D NAND flash memory. To efficiently planarize the large step height associated with vertical structures, a slurry with high polishing performance is required in the CMP process [1,2]. Ceria (CeO2) slurries are widely used in shallow trench isolation (STI) and interlayer dielectric (ILD) CMP processes because of their high selectivity and high polishing performance [3–5], which is due to Ce3+ on the particle surface, which forms a Ce–O–Si bond with silicon oxide (SiO2) substrate to remove films in lump form [6–8].
                  However, the adhesion of the Ce–O–Si bond makes it difficult to remove the residual ceria particles on the wafer surface during the post-CMP cleaning process [9]. In particular, small ceria particles below 50 nm are more difficult to remove from the wafer surface by mechanical and chemical cleaning methods [10,11]. As the ceria particles become smaller, more force is required to detach them from the wafer surface. Therefore, the limitations of small particle removal by chemical and mechanical cleaning methods have been investigated. In this regard, tangential flow filtration (TFF) systems can be used to separate small ceria particles from the slurry before CMP process begins.
                  Filtration systems generally use one of two methods depending on the direction of fluid flow: dead-end filtration or TFF (also called cross-flow filtration). In dead-end filtration, the flow in the filter is perpendicular to the membrane surface, is vulnerable to cake layer formation, and has a short membrane replacement cycles [12]. This method mainly uses as a POU filter to separate large particles that cause scratches and shorten the pad lifetime during the polishing process [13,14]. In contrast to dead-end filtration, the fluid in the TFF method moves parallel to the membrane surface and continuously removes particles on the membrane surface by hydrodynamic forces [15]. This fluid direction helps to reduce cake layer formation, creating a quasi-stationary region that results in a longer lifetime [16,17]. Based on these advantages, the TFF method is generally used for water treatment and purification in biotechnology [18–20]. During purification, the TFF method provides a purified liquid in the permeate direction by removing impurities in the retentate direction [21,22]. In contrast, we applied the TFF method to secure the ceria slurry in the retentate direction, from which small ceria particles were removed in the permeate direction. Because the size of particles to be removed is different depending on the purpose, it is important to understand the parameters that affect the particle separation rate in each direction.
                  In a previous study, we improved cleaning efficiency by 34.7% when a TFF system was applied to the ceria slurry before CMP process [23]. The slurry circulated for 2 h at 1 lpm through a TFF system with a 0.1 
                        
                           μ
                           m
                        
                      membrane pore size, separating 30.7% of ceria particles that were smaller than the pore size. Moreover, the TFF system did not affect the polishing performance of the slurry while maintaining the pH value, zeta potential, and solid concentration. However, it is necessary to understand the correlation between the variables in the TFF system and the separation rate of particles in the slurry.
                  In this work, we investigated the correlations between the particle separation rate of the slurry and the TFF system variables of membrane pore size, transmembrane pressure (TMP), and flow rate. By controlling these parameters, a sufficient separation rate of small particles can be achieved, even when changing from a circulation method to a quicker single-pass type TFF method. Therefore, we fabricated a single-pass type TFF system to increase the separation rate of small particles while minimizing the loss of active particles in a polishing process. Moreover, we evaluated the cleaning efficiency of buff cleaning in a single-pass type TFF system compared with a standard clean 1 (SC1) method.

                  Results and discussion
                  
                     3.1
                     Mechanisms of the cleaning methods and tangential flow filtration system
                     
                        3.1.1
                        Limitations of small ceria particle removal
                        In this study, we investigated removal mechanisms for ceria particles that remain on a wafer surface after the CMP process using chemical and physical cleaning methods. To clarify the difficulties associated with removing small ceria particles, it is necessary to explain the interactions between the particles and the wafer surface during the cleaning process. According to DLVO theory, the adhesion force between the particle and wafer surface was considered to be the Van der Waals force and the electrostatic force [24]. In particular, the ceria particles should also be considered in the Ce–O–Si bonding with the SiO2 wafer surface during polishing [7,8].
                        
                           Fig. 2
                            shows the zeta potential of the SiO2 wafer and ceria slurry as a function of the pH value. Both materials showed a negative charge at pH 9. Based on this result, the electrostatic force between the ceria particles and wafer surface was determined to act as a repulsive force. Therefore, the Van der Waals force and Ce–O–Si bonding should be considered when analyzing the adhesion force between ceria particles and the SiO2 wafer surface. In particular, the ceria particles form stronger chemical bonds with the SiO2 wafer in an alkaline than an acidic solution due to the formation of –OH groups by H2O dissociation [11]. As the size of ceria particles decreases, the Ce3+ ion concentration increases due to the high surface-to-volume ratio [6]. High Ce3+ ion concentrations increase the adsorption affinity with the SiO2 wafer—that is, they lead to a number of chemical bonding [25].
                        As mentioned, small ceria particles form more Ce–O–Si bonds with SiO2 wafers due to their higher surface-to-volume ratio compared to large ceria particles at the same concentration [26]. To break these Ce–O–Si bonds, it required a lot of energy, which makes it difficult to remove small ceria particles from the wafer surface. Chemical and physical cleaning methods were used to remove the residual ceria particles on the wafer surface after the polishing process. A typical chemical cleaning method is SC1, which removes ceria particles by etching the wafer surface slightly [27]. SC1 cleaning has great cleaning performance; however, there is a disadvantage in that it causes a loss of SiO2 film and re-contamination [28].
                        Another method for removing ceria particles from the wafer surface is buff cleaning with deionized water. Although buff cleaning has inferior cleaning performance compared with SC1 cleaning, there is no risk of contamination spreading by additional chemical additives. Buff cleaning removes the particles using drag forces caused by fluid and shear forces acting on pad asperities. Because the contact area between the pad asperity and the wafer is less than 1%, the drag force caused by the fluid is more significant than the shear force [29–31]. Many researchers have studied the parameters of buff cleaning (such as viscosity, fluid velocity, and gap) to improve cleaning efficiency with increased drag force [32–34]. From a physical perspective, the Van der Waals force is represented as a linear function of the diameter of the particles, and the drag force is represented as a quadratic function [32,35]. Thus, it is difficult to remove ceria particles below a certain size, even by simply increasing the drag force in the physical cleaning method.
                        Therefore, we separated the small ceria particles which were difficult to remove from the cleaning process using the TFF system before entering the CMP process. In this study, the standard of the small ceria particles was set below 50 nm, which is a size that is difficult to remove from the wafer surface in the cleaning process [10,11]. To clearly understand the correlation between cleaning efficiency and polishing performance according to particle separation rate, we used the calcined ceria slurry, which has a poor particle size distribution compared with the colloidal ceria slurry [36].

sections.Conclusion:
4
                  Conclusion
                  In the post-CMP cleaning, small ceria particles act as contamination, and they are difficult to remove. The TFF system can improve buff cleaning efficiency by separating small ceria particles in the slurry without chemicals. We identified a correlation between the separation rate of ceria particles and the TFF system variables of membrane pore size, TMP, and flow rate. Furthermore, changes in buff cleaning efficiency were evaluated as a function of the separation rate of ceria particles. The results found that the separation rate of small particles (<50 nm) increased when the pore size increased, and the flow rate of the slurry decreased. However, under high pressure conditions, the TFF system also separated many large ceria particles over 50 nm. Moreover, because the circulation method is time consuming, optimization of a single-pass method was necessary to improve efficiency. Considering these points, a single-pass type TFF system was applied to the ceria slurry for each membrane pore size under low flow rate and pressure conditions. The separation rate of small particles ranged from 26.3% to 42.4%, while also reducing the separation rate of active particles used in polishing process. In addition, the TFF system did not change the slurry properties, such as pH value, zeta potential, and solid concentration, and it also maintained the polishing performance of the slurry. The buff cleaning efficiency of the ceria slurry which applied the single-pass type TFF system was improved by up to 18.1%, and this result showed similar performance to SC1 cleaning.
